title: General Election 2017: How can you talk about politics in the office without arguing? | Leicester Mercury
text:
Comments (0) 
There's only a few weeks to go until the country goes to the polls to decide who elect the next Prime Minister - but should you really talk about it in the office? 
The upcoming battle between Jeremy Corbyn, Theresa May and Tim Farron is likely to provoke some tension in the workplace, especially in light of the Brexit vote. 
So what should employers do? Is an outright ban on politics chat the answer? The Mercury asked Alan Price, chief executive of employment law, HR, and health & safety specialists Croner, in Hinckley: 
While you can't prevent political discussions at work, it is important to remind employees to be respectful. 
Political views are a personal matter that are often deeply held and this can lead to discussions turning confrontational and personal. 
Employers need to ensure that employees are aware of what is, and isn't, acceptable to say in the workplace regarding politics to reduce the risk of political discrimination. 
A ban on employees talking about politics is likely to be difficult to uphold so employers need to be realistic and ensure any talk is legal and conducive to the workplace.
